Foreword

All but two equities and all funds listed in this November monthly pay collection lived up to the ideal of paying annual dividends from a $1K investment exceeding their single share price. Here, in the MoPay batch, lie affordable (yet volatile and risky) bargains. The dogcatcher rule of thumb of one metric ($1,000.00 of invested annual dividend income > 1 share price) fits all!

Now, beyond five years past the 2020 Ides of March Covid market dip, and before the daddy of all other major pullbacks yet to come, the time to buy top yield MoPay dogs may be now.

To learn about the 20 Ideal MoPay equities paying "safer" dividends, see the conclusion of this article, in the Afterword. (You might even start at the afterword and work your way back to the front.)

Actionable Conclusions (1-10): Brokers Estimated Top Ten MoPay Equities Could Net 21.58% to 86.54% Gains By November, 2026

Four of ten top-yield MoPay stocks (shaded in the chart below) were verified as being among the top-ten gainers for the coming year based on analyst one-year target prices. Thus, the Dogcatcher yield-based strategy for this MoPay group, as graded by broker estimates this month, proved 40% accurate.

Estimated dividend payouts from $1000 invested in each of the ten highest-yielding stocks, plus analysts median 1yr target prices for those stocks, as reported by YCharts, produced the gain estimates below. (Note: target prices from lone analysts were not counted.) Ten probable profit-generating trades to November, 2026 were:

Average net gain in dividend and price was 40.47% on $1k invested in each of these ten MoPay stocks. This gain estimate was subject to average risk/volatility 6% greater than the market as a whole.

The Dividend Dogs Rule

Stocks earned the "dog" moniker by exhibiting three traits: (1) paying reliable, repeating dividends, (2) their prices fell to where (3) yield (dividend/price) grew higher than their peers. Thus, the highest yielding stocks in any collection became known as "dogs." More specifically, these are, in fact, best called "underdogs".

October Monthly Pay Dividend Data

Three lists produce numerous actionable conclusions and several more un-numbered results. To draw these conclusions and results, September 29, 2025 closing prices and estimated annual dividends were referenced from YCharts. In the process, monthly pay equity (1) yield and (2) upside potential lists were compared and contrasted against (3) the high yield (and higher risk) MoPay CEICs/ETFs/ETNs list.

Monthly Pay Dividend Qualities

Quarterly, Semi-Annual and Annual dividend investors anxiously await announcements from a firm, fund, or brokerage to learn if their next dividend will be higher, lower, or paid at all.

Monthly pay stocks, funds, trusts, and partnerships inform the holder every four and one third weeks by check and/or statement. If the entity reduces or suspends a payment, the holder can sell out of the investment immediately to avoid future loss of income.

This advantage has been curtailed when companies suddenly cut monthly dividends to save cash. Numerous prominent MoPay firms declared dividend cuts between May and June, 2020, including: Oxford Square Capital Corp; Partners Real Estate Investment Trust; Orchid Island Capital Inc; Cross Timbers Royalty Trust; H&R Real Estate Investment Trust; BTB Real Estate Investment Trust; American Finance Trust Inc; Mesa Royalty Trust; Solar Senior Capital Ltd; Ellington Financial Inc; Dividend Select 15 Corp; Chesswood Group Ltd; Sabine Royalty Trust; TORC Oil & Gas Ltd; Freehold Royalties Ltd; ARC Resources Ltd; Inter Pipeline Ltd; San Juan Basin Royalty Trust; Ag Growth International.

Former MoPay top ten regular by yield. Bluerock Residential announced December 2019 it was retreating to quarterly dividend payments "in keeping with industry tradition." Bluerock Residential company has since gone private and is no longer listed publicly.

That "industry tradition" continued with Armour Residential REIT and Stellus Capital Investment Corp both transitioned to Q Pay in June, 2020. Within three months, however, both SCM and ARR returned to MoPay mode.

Top yield stock for July, 2018, June 2021, and December 2023, Orchid Island Capital, released this cautionary note with its monthly dividend announcements back in 2018: "The Company has not established a minimum distribution payment level and is not assured of its ability to make distributions to stockholders in the future."

ORC directors proceeded to back-up their words with actions cutting the dividend from $0.14 to $0.11 in February, to $0.09 in March, to $0.08 in September, 2018, and to $0.055 for May, 2020. However in August. 2020 ORC monthly dividend increased from $0.06 to $0.065 for September, October, and into 2021.

ORC, however, currently pays a $0.12 monthly dividend (falling from $0.16 in October, 2023) and is again listed here.

The U.S. stock market MoPay segment is volatile, transitive, recovering, and since 2024 has achieved recovery to near full strength. More trades in monthly pay equities are available from Canadian firms, many of which are also listed on U.S. OTC (pink sheet) exchanges. Active listed MoPays priced over $5 number 64 for October 2025.

List One:

US Exchange Traded MoPay Dividend Equities by Yield, Analyst Targets, & Annual Returns

Annual Yield

Top ten of these US exchange listed monthly pay dividend equities showing the best yields for November, represented just two of the eleven Morningstar market sectors. Eight of the ten firms were from the financial services sector: Horizon Technology Finance (HRZN) [1]; Orchid Island Capital [2]; Armour Residential [3]. Two Real Estate representatives placed fourth and ninth, Smart Stop Self Storage REIT (SSST) [4] and Inpoint Commercial Real Estate Income [9]. Thereafter, The financials returned: North American Financial 15 Split (OTCPK:FNCSF) [5]; Dividend 15 Split Corp (OTCPK:DVSPF) [6]; Dividend Growth Split Corp (OTCPK:DDWWF) [7]; Dynex Capital Inc [8]; Canadian Banc Corp (OTCPK:CNDCF) [10], to complete the November MoPay top-ten equities list by yield.

Only twenty-four of these US exchange listed monthly pay dividend equities earned positive grades from analysts in late October. Those twenty-four occupied just three of the eleven Morningstar market sectors. The firms split 1, 13, and 10 between the energy, real estate and financials sectors, respectively. One more in the financial and one in the energy sectors showed negative analyst target grades. Most of the top 60 were unrated by analysts

Annual Returns

Top ten of these US exchange listed monthly pay dividend equities showing the best returns into November, represented three of the eleven Morningstar market sectors. Five of the ten firms were from the financial services sector; four were from real estate; one represented energy and completed the November MoPay top-ten equities list by one year returns.

Yields, Targets, & Returns Summarized

Two on the sixty November MoPay list finished in the top twenty by yields, targets, and returns and both rated IDEAL (with free cash flow yield exceeding dividend yield). The two were: Gladstone Commercial, and Stellus Capital Investment.

List Two (A):

Monthly Pay Dividend Equities by Price Upsides

Results from YCharts, shown below, show 30 MoPay dividend stocks (as of market closing price October 29) compared with the median of analyst target prices one year-out. The ten top-stocks displayed 7.28% to 78.38% price upsides for the coming year.

Five (tinted) of ten on this top upside list were also members of the top ten list by yield.

Furthermore, the top five places on this upside list went to: InPlay Oil [1], Inpoint Commercial Real Estate [2], Gladstone Capital [3], Gladstone Commercial [4], and PennantPark Floating Rate [5].

The lower level (by upside %) five were, Apple Hospitality (APLE) [6], Stelus Capital Investment [7], Ellington Financial (EFC) [8], Orchid Island [9], and Dynex Capital [10] .

Price upside, of course, was defined as the difference between the current price and analyst target one-year median price targets for each stock.

Ten MoPay stocks showing the top-estimated price-gains into November, 2026 were gleaned from 30 selected by yield. Three to nine analysts have historically provided the most accurate median target price estimates.

List Two (B):

31 of 64 Monthly Pay Dividend Equities Show Negative Free Cash Flow Margins

A negative gap between dividend yield and free cash flow yield defines a cash-poor stock. That is, their dividend payout exceeds their cash on hand to pay dividends. Thirty-one of sixty-four November MoPay so infected are considered unsafe to buy.

Remember this dogcatcher yield-based stock-picking strategy is contrarian. That means rooting for (buying) the underdog is productive when you don't already own those stocks. If you do hold those stocks, then you must look for opportune pull-backs in price to add to your position to best improve your dividend yield. Plenty of pull-back opportunities appear to be ahead. Dread the Fed, uncertainty, the toll of the trade tariff Troll and his Taco dealings. Wars are also dreadful.

List Three:

MoPay Dividend Closed End Investment Companies, Exchange Traded Funds, and Notes, by Yield

Eighty top monthly dividend paying Closed End Funds, Exchange Traded Funds and Notes listed below were culled from nearly 800 candidates. The top ten were determined by yields of 24.33% or greater, calculated as of October 29, All 80 show assets under management [AUM] greater than $100M and are priced above $10.00 per share.

The top-ten monthly-paying dividend investment companies, funds, & notes showing the biggest yields per YChart data, featured ONE uncollateralized debt instrument [ETN],

NINE open-ended investment companies [ETFs], and NO closed-ended investment companies [CEICs].

The one top ten uncollateralized debt instrument [ETN] placed sixth: UBS ETRACS Crude Oil Shares Covered Call ETN (USOI) [6]. The top nine open ended investment companies [ETFs] placed first to fifth, and seventh to tenth: YieldMax GOOGL Option Income Strategy ETF (GOOY) [1]; Defiance Nasdaq 100 Enhanced Options & 0DTE in ETF (QQQY) [2]; Roundhill Innov-100 0DTE Covered Call Strategy ETF (QDTE) [3]; Roundhill Russell 2000 0DTE Covered Call Strat ETF (RDTE) [4]; YieldMax AAPL Option Income Strategy ETF (APLY) [5]; KraneShares KWEB Covered Call Strategy ETF (KLIP) [6]; NEOS Bitcoin High Income ETF (BTCI) [7]; YieldMax MSFT Option Income Strategy ETF (MSFO) [8]; Rex AI Equity Premium Income ETF (AIPI) [9 ]; Roundhill S&P500 0DTE Covered Call Strategy ETF (XDTE) [10], to complete the top-ten Exchange Traded Notes, Exchange Traded Funds, and Closed End Funds, into November 25-26.

Compare Equity To Fund Performance

Note that November 2025-26 top-ten equity dividends were again priced 6% below those of the ten funds. Last month they were 4% lower. Last June they were 1% higher. The price differences are caused by the outlandishly high dividends offered by a few of the top equities or funds.

This month the top fund dividend is at 36.14%, whereas the top equity pays just 20.09%. Nevertheless, equities are usually cheaper than funds because equities are not loaded with the high overhead costs of fund management.

Background and Actionable Conclusions

In June 2012 readers suggested the author include these funds, trusts, and partnerships in the MoPay article. A list of MoPay equities to buy and hold in September 2012 resulted from those reader suggestions supplemented with a high yield collection from here. That list was supplemented by an upside potential article in October and a upside vs. buy & hold in November. Another list factored in December 2012 reader comments.

Yield Metrics Showed A 23.19% Disadvantage For The Five Lowest-Priced Of Ten High-Yield MoPay Equities For November

Ten monthly pay stocks were ranked by yield. Those results, verified by YCharts, Seeking Alpha, and YahooFinance, produced the following charts.

Higher priced five MoPay dividend equities, estimated as of October 29, were: Inpoint Commercial; Smart Self Storage; Canadian Banc; Dynex Capital; ARMOUR Residential , whose prices ranged from $8.40 to $16.21.

This distinction between five low-priced dividend dogs and the general field of ten reflects the "basic method" Michael B. O'Higgins employed for beating the Dow. The same technique, you now see, is today useful to find long-term rewarding dogs in the MoPay kennel.

The added scale of projected gains, based on analyst targets, contributed a unique element of "market sentiment" gauging upside potential. It provided a here and now equivalent of waiting a year to find out what might happen in the market. It is also the work analysts got paid big bucks to do.

Caution is advised, however, as analysts are historically 15% to 85% accurate on the direction of change and about 0% to 15% accurate on the degree of the change.

data.title: Infrastructure Development: Building For Innovation
data.description:
This piece is one in a series that delves further into the leading themes emerging from this year’s iteration of our flagship research project, Charting Disruption.

Infrastructure development opportunities are expanding globally due to several powerful structural tailwinds. For example, growing global fragmentation has increased the focus on domestic power generation and manufacturing, creating the need for new power-grid infrastructure and production facilities. Aging infrastructure assets are a challenge for developed economies, requiring repairs or replacements to critical networks. Emerging markets need new infrastructure to support larger, more urban populations. Simultaneously, the adoption of disruptive technologies such as AI, electric vehicles, and renewable energy requires a massive buildout of support infrastructure, such as data centers.

Going into 2026, we expect that these dynamics to create sizable opportunities for companies providing construction materials, equipment, and services around the world.

Key Takeaways

  • Infrastructure development is central to several global structural tailwinds and could require $106 trillion in investments through 2040.1
  • The United States remains a leading market for infrastructure upgrades, with the reshoring of strategic industries strengthening long-term tailwinds.
  • Aging infrastructure assets are likely to continue to create new infrastructure opportunities globally, including in the United States where many infrastructure asset segments are in poor condition.2

Massive Infrastructure Investment Needed as Global Demands Rise

Infrastructure is at the center of nearly every major structural shift transforming the global economy. AI, for example, depends heavily on how quickly data centers and power grid infrastructure can be built. Widespread adoption of EVs, for its part, requires charging systems and supportive electrical grid infrastructure. Meanwhile, rising trade tensions have countries racing to expand domestic manufacturing for strategic technologies, such as AI chips and EV batteries.

Additionally, supporting larger, more urban populations while mitigating impacts from climate change requires a staggering amount of infrastructure, such as modernized power grids, clean water infrastructure, and residential buildings. It is estimated that roughly half of the buildings that will need to exist globally by 2050 have yet to be constructed.3

Through 2040, investments totaling $106 trillion may be needed to meet the world’s infrastructure needs.4 Transport and logistics infrastructure have the highest projected investment requirements at $36 trillion. Energy and power infrastructure require an estimated $23 trillion, while digital infrastructure, such as data centers, could require nearly $20 trillion.5 Social infrastructure, including schools, healthcare facilities, and housing, as well as waste and water, agriculture, and defense infrastructure, could also require trillions in investments. 6

Global Fragmentation Creates New Development Opportunities for U.S. Manufacturing Facilities

The boost for infrastructure development from rising trade fragmentation is particularly evident in the United States. In just the first eight months of the second Trump administration, companies announced nearly $1.25 trillion in investments to expand their U.S. manufacturing footprints.7 Key drivers of this trend are rising geopolitical tensions and shifting federal policies, particularly the implementation of the administration’s extensive tariff scheme.

While the announcements span a variety of industries, much of the planning pipeline is concentrated in strategic areas. Consumer electronics leads with more than $700 billion in announced U.S. investments, although the category is heavily concentrated in just two companies.8 Pharmaceutical manufacturing investments total $290 billion across 18 announcements from both domestic and international drugmakers. Semiconductor manufacturers account for 11% of announced investments, with plans to spend $134 billion on top of the $300 billion announced prior to 2025.9,10

As of July 2025, construction spending on manufacturing accounted for just under 15% of total private construction spending in the United States, a 2.5x increase from January 2021.11,12 We believe the flurry of investments over 2025 could push manufacturing’s share of construction spending higher over the medium to long term.

Aging Infrastructure Is a Common Concern for Developed Economies, Including the United States

Decades-old assets can slow economic growth and hamper the adoption of disruptive technologies. For example, even though electricity can be viewed as essential to economic and social progress, power grids are frequently underfunded and outdated.13 In Japan, over two-thirds of transmission infrastructure is at least 20 years old. Nearly half of all transmission infrastructure in the United States and over 40% of assets in the European Union are also at least two decades old.14

For the United States, inadequate infrastructure conditions extend well beyond the power grid. Despite increased funding over the past four years, the American Society of Civil Engineers only improved the country’s overall infrastructure grade from a C- in 2021 to a C in 2025.15 Half of the assessed categories received either a D or D+, translating to “Poor, At Risk” status. This means that these nationwide systems are in fair to poor condition and “mostly below standard, with many elements approaching the end of their service life.”16

Improving the quality of infrastructure in the United States alone could require $9.1 trillion in investments between 2024 and 2033. Over $5 trillion in funding has been allocated, meaning that a multi-trillion-dollar investment gap still needs to be filled by additional public and private spending.17 Similarly, the European Union faces a $2 trillion infrastructure investment gap when considering expected infrastructure development needs and announced funding through 2040.18

Conclusion: Infrastructure Renaissance Could Emerge from Surging Public and Private Investment

Global infrastructure development is increasingly pivotal to the economies of the future. The adoption of disruptive technologies such as AI, the reshoring of strategic supply chains, and the growth of urban populations all depend on how quickly supportive infrastructure can be built. As these demands rise, so too could opportunities for companies – and investors – across the infrastructure development value chain.

data.title: 2 Discounted CEFs To Generate Monthly Cash Flow
data.description:
Written by Nick Ackerman, co-produced by Stanford Chemist

Picking up closed-end funds at a discount is one of the key opportunities that are presented in the fund structure. However, it isn't just going out and buying a fund at the largest discount and hoping for the best—though with activist investors on the prowl, that can pay off occasionally. Where the real opportunities open up is generally on a fund's relative discount to its historical past.

In shorter periods, we can see some tactical plays as funds that dip to wide discounts can spring back. Over the longer term, can also be a pretty solid guide, though one always has to consider the current environment or any other potentially fundamental changes that a CEF has undergone. Today, we are looking at two funds that get our 'Buy' rating based on their attractive discount levels.

Further, almost all CEFs have a focus on generating relatively higher distribution yields to their investors. With that, both of these names that we are touching on today also deliver monthly distributions to help generate passive monthly cash flow for their shareholders.

#1 XAI Octagon Floating Rate & Alternative Income Trust (XFLT)

  • 1-Year Z-score: -2.51
  • Premium/Discount: -14.14%
  • Distribution Yield: 17.07%
  • Expense Ratio: 3.59%
  • Leverage: 38.19%
  • Managed Assets: $705.5 million
  • Structure: Perpetual

XFLT's objective is to "seek attractive total return with an emphasis on income generation across multiple stages of the credit cycle."

They will do this through "a dynamically managed portfolio of floating-rate credit instruments and other structured credit investments within the private markets. Under normal market conditions, the Trust will invest at least 80% of managed assets in senior secured loans, CLO debt, and equity."

XFLT is invested in a hybrid allocation of collateralized loan obligations, both equity and debt tranches. The fund is then also allocated to a higher composition of senior loan exposure. The CLO space has been getting rocked, and even senior loans have been facing pressure due to the Fed starting to cut rates again.

Since the underlying investment instruments are floating-rate-based investments, these are going to see less income generation moving forward with each Fed cut. That's why we've been seeing funds in this space start to adjust their distributions lower—simply unwinding the distribution increases they had seen previously. I wouldn't be too surprised to see additional cuts here either, as the Fed is projected to continue a downward path to their target rate.

As somewhat of a bonus, thanks to the massive discount that has opened up for the fund, now the actual distribution rate on the NAV comes to 14.66%. That means the portfolio has to generate a materially lower level than what the market price reflects at over 17%. Of course, to reiterate, nearly 15% yield is still quite elevated, and further cutting is likely necessary.

Further pressure has come in the form of credit issues. These underlying instruments, and where XFLT focuses, are in junk-rated territory. That makes them some of the riskiest, and then you put the leverage that is employed by XFLT on top of that.

Speaking of leverage on the fund, the publicly traded 6.5% Series 2026 Term Preferred Shares (XFLT.PR.A) were called, with the redemption date on October 31, 2025. This was as they were able to issue a private placement of Mandatory Redeemable Preferred Shares with a 5.92% fixed rate. A slightly lower rate can mean a bit of easing on their borrowing costs, relatively speaking. However, a greater amount is now outstanding, so on an absolute basis, borrowing costs will rise.

With all that said, there are real risks to consider with this fund, and the outlook isn't all roses and sunshine. On the other hand, it is priced in the dumps now, and that makes it look quite appealing for a longer-term investor to consider starting to add further or take an initial stake.

When the pain stops is anyone's guess. I personally started to add too early, but that's why I've taken a more cautious approach with dollar-cost averaging in, rather than taking a substantial stake all at once. I also continue to reinvest the monthly payout, which will further add a bit every month. As shares sink lower into penny stock territory (below $5 per share), it is possible that they conduct a reverse split, like we saw from Oxford Lane Capital (OXLC) recently.

#2 Flaherty & Crumrine Preferred Income Opportunity Fund (PFO)

  • 1-Year Z-score: 2.48
  • Discount/Premium: -6.36%
  • Distribution Yield: 6.33%
  • Expense Ratio: 1.41% (4.72% including leverage expenses)
  • Leverage: 37.20%
  • Managed Assets: $216 million
  • Structure: Perpetual

PFO's investment objective is "to provide its common shareholders with high current income consistent with preservation of capital." To achieve this, they will invest, "under normal market conditions, at least 80% of its managed assets in a portfolio of preferred and other income-producing securities. Preferred and other income-producing securities may include, among other things, traditional preferred stock, trust preferred securities, hybrid securities that have characteristics of both equity and debt securities, contingent capital securities, subordinated debt, and senior debt."

On the other side of XFLT, we have PFO, a fund primarily invested in preferred securities but also contingent convertible (AT1 bonds) securities as well. Where higher short-term rates helped to boost funds like XFLT to see higher income generation within their portfolio, it hurt preferred investments that are largely fixed-rate.

While XFLT has some fixed-rate borrowings, PFO is also leveraged, but all of its borrowings are floating-rate. They chose not to hedge their borrowings as other fund sponsors had. Looking back, that was clearly the wrong step, but hedging also comes with a cost. Had rates not been so aggressively hiked, it could have led to outperformance, as it had historically done for them not to be hedged.

So they saw their borrowing costs rise while the underlying fixed-rate yields stayed...well...fixed. They had some fixed-to-float exposure, but that primarily only helps over the longer term, as they can take years to kick in to the floating rate part—at which time, the issuer often calls it and replaces it if they can for a cheaper issuance.

Needless to say, that meant less income leftover to support a distribution, and we saw many distribution cuts while rates were rising aggressively—as the portfolio also tanked lower, creating a double-whammy. However, the distribution has now been going back up. It has been a slow process, but the rate cuts have been a much slower process compared to the most aggressive rate hiking cycle we've seen in decades from the Fed.

The current distribution rate of 6.33% can be compared to the 5.91% NAV rate. The discount here isn't as substantial as XFLT, but any discount will help to 'juice' the market yield relative to the NAV rate.

During the period of aggressive rate hikes, sending the payout lower along with a NAV heading lower, as the fund's share price was tanking into a deep discount. That exacerbated the actual pain that investors felt, as the fund had previously traded at a premium regularly. So that was more like a triple-whammy that investors got in this fund.

That is, risk of investing in a CEF is that a discount/premium can work against you, as a discount can always move even wider—or, in this case, a premium drops to a material discount. Though even that discount has been starting to narrow now that rates have mostly stabilized and the Fed has once again begun to cut its benchmark rate.

The fund has seen its discount narrow quite impressively since the double-digit levels, but it still remains historically attractive. Particularly on a short-term basis, we see an elevated 1-year z-score. With that, I wouldn't be adding too aggressively here, but once again, take a dollar-cost average approach.

It's also worth noting that about 50% of the fund is invested in BBB or above credit quality, making it tilt toward a relatively higher quality portfolio that should pose relatively less credit risk. Instead, it is a more interest rate-sensitive fund, as we've touched on.

data.title: Electrification: Securing Power For Advancing Technologies
data.description:
This piece is one in a series that delves further into the leading themes emerging from this year’s iteration of our flagship research project, Charting Disruption.

Global electricity demand is forecast to increase by 50% between year-end 2024 and 2040, led by growth in the United States, India, and China.1 The robust outlook stems from multiple structural trends that are likely to lead to higher power consumption across a range of technologies and industries. Surging AI adoption – resulting in the need for power-intensive data centers – is one of the most notable tailwinds to emerge in recent years. Rising global fragmentation, leading to renewed efforts to expand manufacturing capacity outside of China, is expected to boost industrial electricity consumption. Simultaneously, shifting demographics, climate change, and the electrification of transport and heat are driving power demand growth from consumer appliances and electric vehicles. These dynamics could create sizeable opportunities for companies involved in the electricity and grid infrastructure value chain.

Key Takeaways

  • Global electricity demand could grow by 13,300 terawatt hours (TWh) through 2040, which is nearly equivalent to the current electricity consumption of China and the United States combined.2
  • Data centers are an increasingly significant driver of power demand growth. By 2035, global data center electricity use could rival the power needs of large economies.3,4
  • Many utilities around the world will likely need to expand power generation and grid infrastructure assets, an undertaking that could require $15 trillion in investments through 2035.5

The Power Industry Is Poised for a Dramatic Transformation

Global electricity demand is forecast to skyrocket 50% by 2040.6 This robust outlook largely stems from three key drivers: the ongoing buildout of power-intensive data centers, the electrification of heat and transport, and an anticipated expansion of manufacturing activity in major economies like the United States. At the same time, traditional electricity growth drivers, such as population growth and expanded air conditioning use, are expected to contribute to higher electricity use around the world.

China is expected to remain the largest electricity consumer, with demand forecast to rise from 8,778TWh in 2024 to nearly 14,000TWh by 2040.7 India’s electricity use could more than double from 1,617TWh to 3,474TWh over the same period. Although the United States is forecast to experience the third largest jump, its power market is undergoing a dramatic shift.8 Over the next 15 years, U.S. electricity demand is forecast to increase between 35% and 50%, a substantial reversal from near-flat growth over the past 20 years.9,10

Global Data Center Power Demand Could Grow More Than 4x Between 2024 and 2035

Data centers have emerged as a driving force of rising power demand forecasts around the world. A key reason behind this surge is the growing adoption of generative AI, as large language models often consume large amounts of electricity. For example, a single ChatGPT query can require roughly 10 times the energy of a typical Google search.11

The three major economies driving the AI race are expected to account for the majority of global data center growth. The United States is forecast to remain the leading market, with demand projected to rise from 141TWh in 2024 to nearly 430TWh by 2035.12 China could add just over 300TWh of electricity demand from data centers, while Europe could add nearly 100TWh.13

Globally, data center power demand is forecast to increase from 371TWh in 2024 to 1,596TWh in 2035.14 This level would mean that within a decade, the global data center fleet could require more power than many large economies consumed in 2024, including Brazil, Japan, and Russia.15,16 By 2035, data centers could account for 4.5% of global electricity use, up from a 1.4% share in 2024.17

Modernizing Power Infrastructure Can Create a Multi-Trillion Dollar Opportunity

In many countries, growing electricity needs are compounding at a time when utilities also face mounting security risks from cyberattacks, shifting grid dynamics, and extreme weather. For example, in 2024, Hurricanes Milton and Helene created significant disruptions to power grid infrastructure in the Southeastern United States.

Solving these challenges will likely require trillions of dollars in investments across a variety of power sources, including renewable energy, short- and long-term energy storage, nuclear power, and natural gas. Solar power, wind power, and battery energy storage are forecast to account for a combined 92% of global electricity capacity additions between 2025 and 2040.18 Tech advancements, cost-competitiveness, favorable policies, and corporate power purchases support the robust outlooks for the renewables industry.

The forecasted capacity expansion for nuclear power is smaller, but it is likely to remain a vital solution, particularly for data center operators. Since 2024, the tech sector has emerged as a burgeoning market for traditional and next-gen nuclear power purchase agreements (PPAs).19 In June 2025, for example, Constellation and Meta signed a 20-year PPA for the 1,121-megawatt (MW) Clinton nuclear power plant in Illinois to support Meta’s operations, beginning in 2027.20 Also in June, Amazon and Talen Energy signed a 1,920MW PPA to use the utility’s Susquehanna nuclear power plant in Pennsylvania to power Amazon Web Services' (AWS) data centers in the region.21 Small modular reactor (SMR) developers, such as Oklo and NuScale, also signed agreements to supply power to data centers in the future.22,23

In total, nearly $15 trillion in global investments could be required for electricity generation facilities and power grid infrastructure through 2035, with the largest investments expected for renewables and power grids.24 By 2050, total investment needs for power grids are projected to more than double.25

Conclusion: Power Is Pivotal to the Modern Economy

The advancement of disruptive technologies, such as AI and electric vehicles, requires an unprecedented power capacity expansion. Meeting future power needs likely calls for large-scale deployment of available technology, including nuclear power, renewables, cutting-edge energy storage systems, and hydrogen-powered solutions. For investors, we believe this transformation of the global power network presents powerful, long-term opportunities.

data.title: IonQ: Quantum Progress Meets Market Reality
data.description:
When I first analyzed IonQ (IONQ) it was a scientific frontrunner still searching for commercial validation. Since then, the stock has surged 113%, reflecting growing conviction in its execution and financial strength. The company raised 2025 guidance to $82–$100 million, beat Q2 revenue by 15%, and secured a $1 billion investment from Susquehanna, boosting cash to $1.68 billion.

Ahead of Q3 2025 earnings next week, with revenue expected to rise over 117% year-over-year, IonQ’s focus shifts from proving technology to scaling commercialization through Oxford Ionics, Lightsynq, and early networking deployments that could define the next phase of quantum monetization.

As such, I maintain a hold rating, accumulating on pullbacks, recognizing IonQ’s technological leadership while noting that its extended valuation limits substantial upside in the near to medium term.

Expanding the Quantum Empire

IonQ posted a revenue of $20.7 million for the Q2 2025, thus beating the estimate by a margin of 15%. This may be justified based on the acceleration of projects for the U.S. Department of Energy and Air Force Research Laboratory.

The purchases of Oxford Ionics and Lightsynq fundamentally changed IonQ’s technological roadmap. Oxford Ionics brings ion-trapping on a chip that allows for the integration of millions of qubits with current silicon manufacturing, while Lightsynq provides photonic interconnects to connect these chips in modular group configurations to allow for the achievement of IonQ’s roadmap of 800 logical qubits in 2027 and 80,000 in 2030.

This was addressed by Oxford Ionics’ co-founder, Chris Ballance, who pointed out that 95% of the hardware overlaps with IonQ’s existing designs, so there is immediate access to mature fabrication processes and ‘trillions in prior semiconductor R&D,’ giving IonQ a substantial cost advantage, with IonQ’s expected logical qubit cost being one to two orders of magnitude lower than others.

IonQ, on the other hand, has expanded far beyond the realm of computation. The addition of the ID Quantique and Capella contracts has cemented IonQ’s place in not only computation but also in earth-based networks and satellite communications as well, as the only company with functioning technology in all three areas. The QKD solutions offered by IDQ are currently safeguarding information for world governments and financial institutions, while the satellites from Capella Technology Corporation will offer worldwide secure entanglements.

IonQ Q3 2025 Preview

IonQ is expected to announce third-quarter earnings for the year 2025 on November 5, projecting revenues of $26.99 million and EPS of -$0.44 compared to over 117% growth from the previous year during the same period. Notably contributing to the company’s excellent performance in Q2, where it beat Street estimates by posting revised full-year revenue estimates within the band of $82 to $100 million, the company’s balance sheet remains strengthened at $1.68 billion in cash after receiving an equity investment of $1 billion from Susquehanna.

Momentum is expected to continue while IonQ converts the backlog related to contracts with the government, hyperscalers, and enterprises by integrating Oxford Ionics and Lightsynq to further advance the hardware roadmap. The company is targeting 800 logical qubits in 2027 and 80,000 in 2030 to scale through the company’s technology in semiconductor-based fabrication and photonic interconnects.

The company would be executing on backlog, Oxford Ionics integration, and early quantum networking revenue related to ID Quantique and Capella in Q3. Marginal expansion would continue due to increased investments in R&D, yet IonQ has enough capital to make these investments without dilution.

In essence, IonQ is implementing an aggressive roadmap but in a position of strength in terms of finances. The company ended Q2 2025 with $656.8 million in cash, which increased to $1.68 billion after it received an equity investment of $1 billion from Susquehanna, which was priced at a 25% premium to the last close. The deal is the single biggest in the quantum industry, leaving IonQ debt-free and well-funded to 2030.

Operating expenses increased to $181 million in Q2, reflecting IonQ’s growth in R&D investments and the integration of new subsidiaries. The company posted an adjusted EBITDA loss of $36.5 million, primarily due to a 231% increase in year-over-year spending on Research & Development. The CFO left little doubt about his spending preferences with $1.7 billion to spend.

While it has significant losses in the near term, IonQ's model emphasizes capability compounding rather than spending management. The growing list of hybrid contracts and primitive production solutions portends well for IonQ to turn adjusted EBITDA positive in the current decade.

Apps Shift from Research to Revenue

One question investors always ask is when quantum computing becomes relevant to businesses. That question is being answered by IonQ.

The collaborative effort with AstraZeneca, Nvidia, and AWS has resulted in a 20x speedup in drug discovery simulations, thus establishing the real-world benefit. The other projects with Oak Ridge National Laboratory, General Dynamics, and Ansys seek to apply IonQ solutions to optimization problems in logistics and the efficiency of the energy grid, thereby establishing the real-world revenue from hybrid solutions today.

The software stack at IonQ has transformed itself into a vital barrier to competition. What began with simple control of qubits has expanded to include an in-house OS, job scheduler, and chemistry/AI-specific repositories on top of it. The manner in which companies start with hybrid workloads and scale to full quantum has locked in revenue streams with strong SaaS-like characteristics.

Valuation: The Quantum Premium

At around $61 per share, IONQ commands an enterprise value of roughly $20.7 billion, translating to a forward EV/Sales multiple of 226.9x and a Price/Sales ratio of 266x, both far exceeding the sector median of around 3.6x. While traditional valuation ratios like P/E or EV/EBITDA remain meaningless in the quantum space, the premium highlights IonQ’s scarcity value and leadership position.

Compared to peers such as Rigetti (RGTI) (EV/Sales 1,519x) and D-Wave (QBTS) (445x), IonQ’s valuation, though steep, appears relatively moderate given its superior growth, institutional backing, and full-stack quantum integration spanning computing, networking, and space-based systems.

Commercialization Timing Remains the Critical Variable

The most significant risk to IonQ, however, is the delay in commercialization. IonQ can potentially offer fault-tolerant technology before 2030, but monetizing it would require validating sustained consumer demand and scalability beyond piloting.

IonQ has planned very aggressively, with goals for tens of millions of qubits and establishing quantum networks worldwide, and while integrating Oxford Ionics and Lightsynq seamlessly would allow it to expedite milestones, any delay in it can potentially reschedule them.

High R&D investments with negative operating cash flow can potentially dilute the equity if it spends more on R&D with less expected revenue in the initial phase, even with the current cash reserve of $1.6 billion.

Bottom Line

The current financial situation of IonQ is one of heavy investment and not of weakness. Its unique IP, sovereign relationships, and plan to deliver large-scale quantum solutions mean that IonQ is on the verge of transitioning from being a speculative innovation play to being a full-fledged platform play, where any kind of valuation multiple becomes absolutely irrelevant to the situation.

data.title: LGI Homes: Poor Timing, What's Next?
data.description:
Introduction

My timing on LGI Homes (LGIH) has been poor to say the least - after writing them up as an attractive investment in December 2024, their quoted value has fallen 50%+. And this is largely justified as their demand has worsened thanks to competitive and macro pressures, two variables I vastly underestimated.

The go-forward question, however, remains: is this just a temporal deterioration that stabilizes, or a structural one that would then support their current price? I find the former more likely and correspondingly see various paths for outperformance, but I’m still not buying.

Sales: Share Loss Structural?

Here’s the year-over-year financial summary: sales have gone from $602M to $483M as their community absorption rate declined from 4.3x to 3x, more than offsetting their growth in communities from 128 to 146 (ASPs were roughly flat at $365K). Total closings declined from 1,655 to 1,323.

Included in those figures is a mix of both their Wholesale and Retail business. Parsed out, Wholesale closings actually grew year-over-year from 117 homes last year to 237 in Q2, with revenue correspondingly growing from ~$36M to ~$71M today. Retail, however, materially weighed on results - total closings declined from 1,538 to 1,086, with revenue declining from ~$566M to ~$412M. So, when we’re thinking about the sales decline, we’re really contextualizing the decline in their Retail business.

Digging in, I think this decline reflects a mix of both market-related and competitive pressures. Management kicked off the Q2 call noting that “elevated mortgage rates contributed to the affordability pressures weighing on entry-level buyers,” and that “heightened economic uncertainty has created a softer sales environment, which buyers are still exploring the idea of home ownership, but are taking longer to make decisions and, in some cases, choosing to delay their purchases.”

Some of this seems to have some qualitative truth - i.e., it’s not inconceivable that consumers are deferring home purchases amid today’s economic climate. Indeed, from one angle, there has been a slight uptick in FHA mortgage delinquencies in 2025. Or, alternatively, PulteGroup (PHM) has seen a single-digit decline in orders, citing that while “consumers remain engaged in the home buying process … they are proceeding with caution given concerns,” so industry conditions are not better, to say the least.

However, when I zoom out on the landscape, we can see some of LGI’s competitors, like Meritage Homes (MTH) and Lennar (LEN) reporting roughly flat year-over-year orders and closings. Furthermore, rates are about the same, so I don’t really buy this argument that they’ve lost a material number of customers for macro reasons. And we can see industry data showing a roughly similar demand level year-over-year for new home sales across the U.S.

Now, that’s not to say there’s some general market softness; however, there’s clearly a wide disconnect between the demand changes that LGI has seen and the rest of the industry. If, then, LGI’s demand reflected a change in market factors - e.g., interest rates, uncertainty - we’d see a similar demand impact on some of their competitors, but this clearly isn’t being reflected.

It is true that part of LGI’s absorption decline stems from a “one-time”-ish impact from the addition of new communities. That is, new communities tend to be, on average, less productive in their initial phases, so as they’ve increased the mix of these (from 128 last year to 146 today), that should have slightly reduced their absorption rate. However, we know this was only part of the degradation, as total closings were down despite more communities, implying their “existing” communities sold many fewer homes today than last year.

The only logical conclusion from this, then, is that they lost customers to some of their competitors, as evidenced by the referenced data above. And there seems to be a reasonable explanation: increased incentives by competitors. Let’s take Lennar as an example. In Q3 last year, Lennar posted 22.5% gross margins - today, those margins are 17.5%, and that’s not because costs grew. It’s because, as Lennar points out, they’ve increased their incentives offered. D.R. Horton (DHI) too saw their gross margins decline ~200 bps to ~22%, with approximately half attributed to increased incentives.

Concurrently - and importantly - LGI has not really been increasing their incentives at the same rate. ASPs were just marginally higher year-over-year at ~$365K, and had it not been for increased Wholesale mix, the ASP would have actually been a little higher thanks to the “geographic mix” in the quarter. This trend reflects that (1) they’re not materially reducing listed pricing anywhere and (2) there’s no material pressure from previously reported trends of customers trending down to lower square footage homes that have a lower price.

Now, they can keep prices unchanged but increase their incentives (COGS) offered. To this end, LGI’s adjusted gross margins are indeed down 150 bps year-over-year, and part of this does indeed stem from increased incentives, which they confirmed back at the start of the year and have noted on Q1 and Q2 calls. However, considering that part of the gross margin decline also came from increased Wholesale mix and operating deleverage, the increase in incentives could have conceivably only been something like 60-80 bps of that. So, compared to what we’ve seen from someone like Lennar, the improvement in their competitors’ value proposition seemingly exceeds LGI’s improvement, supporting this hypothesis.

Inversely, there’s not really any other great explanation for the decline in demand year-over-year (materially speaking). One could suggest a share loss to apartments (a considered alternative by their customers), which I suppose has maybe some merit, but not that much. CoStar released data for Q2 2025 showing apartment rents nationally growing year-over-year in the first half of 2025 and in Q2 specifically, not necessarily something consistent with a structural shift to apartments.

So, I’m largely at odds with management's take on what’s been driving the decline in Retail closings. They’ve been chalking it up to “affordability” or “market” degradation, but that simply doesn’t square away with the data I’m seeing. Share loss appears to be the better explanation as customers find more attractive prices from competitors.

If this is true, what do we make of absorption rates going forward? They’re guiding for ~1.2K closings in Q3 across 145 communities, or an absorption rate of ~2.75x. Typically, there’s some seasonally driven decline from Q2 here, so this isn’t terribly concerning, but clearly, their guidance reflects that today’s demand was not driven by some major one-time issue - this is a good reflection of current (weakened) demand conditions. And there also doesn’t appear to be any predicted, abnormal pressure from anticipated Wholesale closing declines. On a run rate basis, then, absorption rates appear to be about 2.8x-ish on an annual basis.

When I think about where this could trend to, I envision a few different ends of the outcome range. On one end, it’s conceivable that competitors continue to price even lower (increase incentives) while LGI remains steadfast on maintaining their margin. This, however, doesn’t appear sustainable, as I believe LGI would ultimately reduce price to retain customers - they know their price elasticity better than I do, but at some point, the price reduction would be smaller than the cost savings from lower volume.

And indeed, they admitted on the Q2 call to “leaning” into more incentives lately, which would support this go-forward approach. Or said differently, they’re guiding for 24.5% adjusted gross margins in Q3, which would be 100 bps lower than the 25.5% reported in Q2. Their explanation on the call was that they “...always want more pace, leading to our discussion on gross margin, we're forecasting slightly lower gross margin because we are leaning into incentives, especially on the older aged inventory.” So, I find it reasonable that LGI starts to more closely match their competitors' incentive changes, thus reducing share loss.

Now, is it possible that the industry sustains a lower margin profile beyond today’s levels? It’s not inconceivable. Looking at Lennar again, we can see that their current high-teens gross margins are lower than their low-20% gross margins historically. And if we run some over-simplistic math on returns-on-tangible-capital, Lennar is posting sub-10% returns now, or average-to-below-average at this point. So, we’re clearly closer to the bottom range of sustainable rational outcomes, but I personally wouldn’t rule out an extended period - say, 2-3 years - of below-average margins across the industry. Things take time to turn, and the world doesn’t always operate rationally.

But if we are at the bottom of the range, though, in terms of how far players will take their price, and we also assume that LGI will start matching incentives to a roughly similar magnitude, a long-term absorption rate of 3x would make sense to me.

The alternative end of the spectrum is pretty much just the inverse - prices return to historical averages as each company attempts to earn a reasonable return on capital (development costs), which would essentially drive a good chunk of demand back to LGI as they wouldn’t increase prices as much as competitors implicitly would. In the scenario, LGI could certainly be doing 4x+ absorption rates.

Now, there’s a final element here, which is just general market demand levels. At the moment, there appears to be some decent stability, or perhaps slightly worse conditions than last year. When I zoom out, however, we’re not in some abnormal, unsustainable demand territory that’s artificially propped up. That is, new home sales are about where they were pre-COVID, which more or less matches long-term historical averages.

Where this goes from here, I don’t think anyone really knows. Per history, we could maintain stability around these levels, or we could see increased demand from external drivers (lower rates), or the opposite (higher rates). Sustainably speaking, however, I’m fine assuming some 10% bound around those absorption rates. That is, I think there’s a range of outcomes where LGI is doing 2.75x absorption rates over time and an outcome where they’re doing 4.5x. Layer on another 0.25x from new community rate maturity, and we’ll call it 3-4.75x. And in both scenarios, I don’t mind assuming 0-1% cost inflation to their current $365K ASP.

Ultimately, the biggest assumption I’m making is that the declines we’ve seen versus last year are not perpetual, but just stemming from a widened price gap. At some point, either (1) this stops, or (2) LGI increases incentives accordingly to maintain share before it stops. But I don’t find it sustainable long-term for the industry to price materially lower than they’re currently realizing, otherwise returns-on-capital would seemingly fall to uninvestable territory. And as far as new entrants and/or structural market changes, there are worthy items to consider, but none that I think materially change the long-term picture for LGI.

The final variable is their long-term community count. As referenced above, this grew quite a bit year-over-year, from 128 to 146, with LGI opening up new communities across all regions. My conclusion hasn’t really changed here - I still think there’s room for them to grow to 200+ over time, and their belief hasn’t really changed either, as they note that “[d]irectionally, it should be increasing.” In the meantime, though, their previously stated guidance for 160+ by year-end is not likely. Indeed, they’re guiding for 145 in Q3 with the pullback due to economic reasons (lower returns on capital).

And it’s true - historically, they’ve posted returns on equity of ~20%, but given the current demand conditions, those returns are closer to 8-10% on a run rate basis, or about average. So, there are two extremes here. On the one hand, they may ultimately decide that notwithstanding economics recovering to historical levels, they’d open new communities anyway and grow to, say, 200. The other extreme, however, which is more evidenced by recent moves, is that they materially curtail community growth and send those dollars back to shareholders.

I’m personally assuming path 1 is more likely - i.e., they grow. Consistent with this model, they’re going to have to front about $1B+ in capital via inventory growth to support another ~50 communities. Of course, this varies depending on community size, but I expect that to remain relatively consistent with today’s profile. And it also depends on how much inventory they want to carry - as they noted on the call, they’ll be reducing inventory in the near term.

All considered, then, my model looks something like this. I have a community count of 200, from which I contextualize there to be two scenarios - one in which they post 3x absorption rates and another where they post 4.75x. With $390K as an ASP, sales would range from ~$2.8B to ~$4.4B.

Margins: Sales Dependent

LGI’s adjusted gross margin declined 150 bps to 25.5%, and GAAP EBIT margin declined 300 bps to 8.2%. Management called out the gross margin decline on the call, citing “...higher percentage of wholesale closings and, to a lesser extent, higher lot costs and higher capitalized interest as a percentage of revenue as well as reduced operating leverage…”

The capitalized interest variable is excluded in adjusted gross margins, but the rest of the variables make sense - Wholesale was indeed higher and carries lower gross margins, and the reduced absorption rates result in less fixed cost leverage, although this is a smaller percentage of COGS as most of COGS is comprised of the individual home construction (variable costs). Also, it’s worth recalling that back in Q1, they were seeing increased costs, although it’s possible these have yet to fully flow through yet.

As I’ve discussed above, though, a good chunk - despite being unmentioned - of the gross margin decline likely had to do with increased incentives. That is, while ASPs are roughly unchanged, incentives - rate buydowns, closing costs - have increased, increasing their COGS relative to sales.

With respect to OPEX, this declined with G&A relatively unchanged, while selling expenses declined from ~$53M to ~$41.6M. They cited “more efficient advertising spend” as the reason for the selling expense decline, which I tend to contextualize as just lower ad spend. It’s worth pointing out that for the first half of the year, advertising spend is actually “higher” despite lower sales, so increased “efficiency” seems moot.

Qualitatively speaking, though, selling expenses should have had two mixed changes. For one, the increase in community count entails increased headcount - sales reps and managers - to support those communities. Countering this, however, was a decrease in the absorption rates/closings that reduced their sales commission expense. And this latter variable should have driven the bulk of the year-over-year selling expense decline, more than offsetting the headcount cost increase.

Thinking about what this means going forward, I don’t find it to be all that complex, as sales are really going to be the driver of long-term margins, or more specifically, closings. Right now, the 8.2% EBIT margins translate into ~8%-ish on an annual run rate basis (Q2 is a decently average quarter per year).

If we think about scenario 1, where they earn ~$2.8B in sales, this entails an absorption rate roughly equal to today’s run rate and a higher community count. I’m assuming in this scenario, though, that competitors remain aggressive on incentives and that LGI would choose to more or less match them, but I’m not assuming it materially degrades beyond today’s conditions (a potentially perilous assumption). As I referenced above, adjusted gross margins are guided to 24.5% in Q3, reflecting LGI’s willingness to match competitive conditions.

So relative to today, based on industry margins starting to encroach on the lower end of returns on capital, if we assume that they remain here long-term, this would translate into another 100 bps EBIT margin headwind. Layering on minimal additional operating leverage as my absorption rate estimate remains unchanged, and long-term EBIT margins would look like 7%.

Scenario 2 would simply be a lot of the opposite. Absorption rate would return to 4x+ levels, implying that industry prices/margins improve and that LGI would be able to retain at least their current gross margins. Layer on, then, the additional operating leverage per community, and that would probably translate into a margin closer to 10%, more consistent with their history when absorption rates were much higher.

Valuation

I touched on this earlier, but two capital allocation paths could unfold - they can acquire inventory to grow communities, or send FCF back to shareholders. I’m assuming they’ll invest in inventory to support future community growth as noted earlier (to what I think will be ~$1B+).

Now, I’ll just reiterate what I’ve noted in prior articles, which is that they don’t *have* to acquire all new inventory. That is, they’re running inventory at ~185% of sales, a level that is far higher than they justifiably need (the delta is management reportedly finding attractive prices). Thus, it could be that community growth to the 200 mark entails using a mix of already purchased inventory and newly acquired inventory, which would materially change the cash flows (and thus, IRR). For conservatism's sake, I’m assuming inventory remains at these levels and shareholders don’t get this benefit yet.

Put together, here’s how I’m contextualizing the prospective IRR. In one scenario, I think LGI could be doing sales and EBIT of $2.8B/$197M over time (FY35). If that’s realized and remains at a structural, sustainable level, investors would earn something like a 7-8% IRR. On the other hand, if reality is the second scenario ($4.4B/$445M), I calculate an IRR closer to 12-13%. (For more specifics, I’m taking their EBIT, subtracting tax, capex, and their inventory investment along the way to calculate the go-forward free cash flow.)

Does this make for an attractive bet? Well, it depends on your opportunity cost. But from an absolute return perspective, it’s an okay return per what I’d deem a reasonable range of outcomes. Again, the key assumption that I’m making is that LGI is not structurally broken such that they’re a perpetual share loser. And the other key assumption that I’m making is that the housing market or competitive conditions don’t collapse in 2-5 years, neither of which are certain, and this frankly scares me from an investment perspective.

This is an important one. If, for whatever reason, the industry sees prolonged demand reductions and/or prolonged pricing irrationality, that could easily knock a good 100-200 bps off an investor’s return. And that's not considering other random variables such as tariffs. On the other hand, though, there is the conceivable scenario that they materially reduce inventory to lower (sustainable) levels and that materially adds to the IRR in this event.

Conclusion

Having purchased LGI at materially higher levels, there’s this psychological urge to assume that (1) since I don’t believe the business is broken and (2) conditions are worse off today than they were then, (3) the IRR must be attractive today. And in some scenarios, I think LGI will outperform from today—and materially—but it’s not obvious that’ll be the realized scenario. For that reason and given other investments out there, LGI will remain just a tiny percentage of my portfolio.

data.title: Cenovus Energy: Raking In The Cash
data.description:
Just when you thought all the "fun" was over with, Cenovus Energy (CVE) posted a big earnings beat complete with a lot of cash flow while raking in the cash from selling the two refineries jointly owned with Phillips 66 (PSX). Thermal companies normally cash flow rather generously on their own without big news like this. Still, if anyone was wondering where the cash was coming from to finance the MEG Energy (OTCPK:MEGEF) acquisition (where the vote was delayed one more time), the answer is a very unusual "the company raised the cash all by itself". There is a whole lot going on here, and it all appears to be positive for shareholders. The company may still borrow money to finance the acquisition. But it is also quite capable of raising whatever cash is needed.

The last article mentioned that the final offer for MEG Energy was raised a little bit, which got Strathcona (OTCPK:STHRF) to vote its shares in favor of the acquisition. But a regulatory inquiry forced a postponement of the vote for another week until next week. That postponement allowed the sale of the refineries to close and the company to report a flood of incoming cash (as in billions of cash).

Earnings

Similarly, earnings went way past positive. Management has long been working with a group of acquired assets to get those assets running in an optimal fashion. This company has long been known for its low-cost upstream operations.

But the acquired refineries were another matter entirely. Those refineries needed a lot of work. Now that work seems to be bearing some fruit that investors can actually see.

(Note: Cenovus is a Canadian company that reports using Canadian dollars unless otherwise noted.)

The huge jump in earnings translated into one of the largest free cash flow funds reported in recent memory. Now much of the excess funds went to buying back stock because, as management reported, nearly C$1 billion in shares were repurchased.

This has delayed a return of the net debt back to the net debt target yet again. But it is also a sign of the fact that this investment grade company considers that debt well within easy handling range. But it also means that the stock price represents such value that it is worth deferring the debt goal for a bit.

Once the acquisition of MEG Energy closes, there could well be some more noncore sales of assets to quickly keep the net debt measurement within an allowable range (or long-term goal range). This company has long been known for making acquisitions and quickly fixing the balance sheet to where it wants it to be. This coming acquisition should be no exception.

Refining

Meanwhile, steady progress is being made with the refining system.

As shown above, management has been working on the acquired refining system probably ever since the acquisition some years back. However, the improvement projects are now getting to the point where the progress shown above is getting to the point where results are becoming apparent to investors.

Understand that just the acquisition of refining capacity allows this company to report that significant amounts of production bypass the issues with selling a discounted product on the open market. That issue has long plagued company results (and held back the stock price as a result).

However, there was clearly more money to be made by optimizing the acquired refining system. Unfortunately, progress is relatively slow at one turnaround project at a time. I have covered some of this in the past because only the larger, more significant projects really had any effect on results. But now, the cumulative effects of all the improvements made are becoming apparent, as shown above. There is likely more progress coming in the future.

I would expect that the MEG Energy acquisition would raise the priority for still more refining capacity through construction of that capacity or by yet another acquisition when a suitable deal presents itself.

Throughput

This company is not afraid to hold back production when market conditions are less than optimal. One of the contributors to the big quarter was a whole lot of production, as shown below. Now this rather favorable quarter is going to make for a tough comparison next year. Fortunately, that is not yet on the market's radar. Even when it does get to be a market consideration, the MEG Energy acquisition will likely help comparisons by the time this quarter arrives next year.

Summary

The sale of the refinery interests netted C$1.8 billion on October 1. This and the decision to increase the number of shares offered to roughly 50% of the total offer to acquire MEG Energy may make this one of the more conservative deals I have covered.

Meanwhile management continues to both grow production and improve the operations of the assets managed. A combination of decisions resulted in a quarter with a lot of free cash flow just when it was needed. This is an understated characteristic of above average management. The cash arrived at just the right time.

Cenovus Energy continues to be a strong buy idea as the now much larger company begins a transition from a growth story towards a growth and income story. Opportunistic acquisitions and sales will continue to be a material part of the company's future. That may well mean that the average return of these shares is likely to be in the mid-teens over the long-term.

The oil and gas industry continues to be largely out of favor in the current market. So, there could be some recovery potential that would result in a higher valuation in the future for the same results currently posted.

Risks

There is a regulatory inquiry that has delayed the meeting on the approval of the acquisition of MEG Energy. That regulatory inquiry could potentially derail the whole acquisition idea, or it could make the acquisition more costly than anticipated.

This company continues to benefit from advancing technology that has improved many of the deals made over time. Technological advances can theoretically stop at any time. There are no guarantees or assurances that technology will continue to advance to provide cost savings.

Future commodity prices are volatile and have low visibility. A severe and sustained downturn of those prices could materially change the future of the company.

data.title: U.S. Health Insurer Shares Stumble After Q3 Earnings As Cost Pressures Mount
data.description:
Shares in US health insurers struggled after the release of third quarter results, which were marked by rising costs and political uncertainty.

Of the five largest publicly traded US managed care insurers, all but Humana Inc. (HUM) have released their third quarter results since the earnings season began Oct. 21 with Elevance Health Inc. (ELV).

Since Oct. 20, Elevance, UnitedHealth Group Inc. (UNH) and The Cigna Group (CI) saw their stock prices fall 9.1%, 5.4% and 19.5%, respectively. The sharpest decline among managed care insurers was recorded by Molina Healthcare, Inc. (MOH), which fell 23.5%.

The drops exceeded the declines in the S&P 500 and the S&P Insurance Index, which fell 2.47% and 2.15%, respectively, during the same period.

Costs on the rise

A common issue affecting the sector's third quarter earnings calls is ongoing cost pressure, primarily related to government-subsidized Medicaid and Medicare Advantage plans.

After a challenging 2025 for industry leader UnitedHealth, the managed care insurer again highlighted the high costs associated with its Medicaid plans, which experienced heightened acuity levels since state-led procedural disenrollment resumed in March 2023 following the COVID-19 pandemic.

The path to Medicaid recovery will be challenging, as states have not funded the program in line with actual cost trends, according to comments made during an Oct. 28 earnings call by Tim Noel, CEO of UnitedHealthcare, UnitedHealth's insurance arm.

"While we're making steady progress in bridging this gap with states, the mismatch between rate adequacy and member acuity will likely extend through 2026," Noel said.

Similarly, Molina CEO Joseph Zubretsky lamented a "very challenging medical cost environment" during an earnings call and said that Medicaid rates may not be adequate.

"Our early 2025 rate increases were sufficient at the beginning of the year, but as medical cost trends increased beyond those rates, our [medical cost ratio increased each quarter]," Zubretsky said. "The rate updates we received later in the year and risk corridors did not provide an adequate buffer."

Molina's Medicaid medical cost ratio reached 92% during the quarter, according to Zubretsky, while its senior-aimed Medicare plan hit 93.6% as high levels of utilization continued. However, even Molina's marketplace plans were not immune to rising costs, as plans purchased through state exchanges had a medical cost ratio of 95.6%, significantly higher than expected, according to the CEO.

ACA issues loom

Rate issues are not limited to Medicaid, as UnitedHealth joined a growing chorus of insurers expecting to be affected by changes in the Affordable Care Act (ACA) markets.

ACA plans, which are offered through state-based marketplaces and directly from insurers rather than through an employer, have been under scrutiny as the extension of tax credits to lower plan costs has become a key issue for the ongoing federal government shutdown. While the issue remains unresolved, most insurers have already priced in the expectation that the tax credits will not be extended.

UnitedHealth's insurance arm submitted rate filings in nearly all of the 30 states where it offers ACA plans, reflecting an average rate increase of over 25%, according to Noel. Consequently, the company expects its ACA membership to drop significantly, Noel said.

"Where we are unable to reach agreement on sustainable rates, we are enacting targeted service area reductions," Noel said. "We believe these actions will establish a sustainable premium base while likely reducing our ACA enrollment by approximately two-thirds."

Despite these challenges, analysts at J.P. Morgan ranked the insurer's stock "overweight," noting that the company expects to expand margins in 2026 through improvements in Medicare Advantage and commercial plans, which will offset the expected margin contraction in Medicaid.

"We see this as not necessarily dissimilar from commentary in the second quarter; however, with the benefit of several more months of claims/trend progression, we think the incremental visibility underlines this positive commentary," the analysts wrote.

The ACA rate repricing may prove to be a more significant challenge for Centene Corp. (CNC), which has a disproportionately large number of members in the plans compared to its similarly sized competitors.

During a third quarter earnings call, Centene CEO Sarah London touted the benefits of extending ACA tax credits and said Centene believes "these tax credits offer critical support for hard-working Americans, small business owners, and rural healthcare infrastructure."

Centene received a "neutral" rating from J.P. Morgan, and analysts cautioned about ongoing cost impacts.

"On balance, we continue to view Centene an execution story with wide error bars in 2026, albeit one showing progress on execution, and we expect much of the focus will be on proving out assumptions and how Centene is able to recover ACA Exchange margins in 2026, with both factors needing to see further progress before investors turn more constructive," the analysts wrote.
